results.title: The Snowy : A Dream of Growing Up
results.creator_credit: Stephen Ramsey, Siobhan McHugh and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Australia’s Snowy Mountains Scheme is one of the world’s greatest engineering feats. The project to bring water to the dry west was built between 1949 and 1974, employing 100,000 people, many of them migrants who brought with them changes that have shaped Australia. This film documents Australia’s ambitious project using interviews and historical film. Based on the book “The Snowy : the People Behind the Power” by Siobhan McHugh.

results.title: The Snows of Kilimanjaro
results.creator_credit: Henry King, Darryl F. Zanuck and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A hunter lies wounded in Africa and while waiting for help looks back over his life and loves. Hollywood version of a portable Hemingway, with reminiscences of several novels stirred into a lush and sprawling mix of action and romance, open spaces and smart salons. A big popular star film of its time. Starring Gregory Peck, Susan Hayward and Ava Gardner.

results.title: The Snowman (K)
results.creator_credit: Dianne Jackson, John Coates and Snowman Enterprises
results.brief_description: A young boy dreams that his snowman comes to life. Together they share the perils and joys of winter. This animated film uses muted pastels coupled with an exquisite orchestral score to make this non-verbal Christmas tale an experience for all seasons. Based on the book by Raymond Briggs.

results.title: The Snow queen
results.creator_credit: Martin Gates, Carrington Productions and Martin Gates Productions
results.brief_description: Based on Hans Christian Anderson’s fairy tale, this is a story of kidnapping, magic and the heroic adventure of a young girl, Ellie, to thwart the evil Snow Queen who plots to turn the world to ice. After her brother is kidnapped by the Snow Queen to help her build a mirror to deflect the sun and freeze the planet, the courageous Ellie begins a journey with a reluctant bird named Peep. With a little help from magic she sets out to rescue her brother and defeat the Snow Queen. Released by Warner Brothers Family Entertainment this is an engaging story of adventure and the classic triumph of good over evil.

results.title: The Snow queen
results.brief_description: Gerda, a little girl who sets out on an amazing journey to find her friend Kay, who has fallen under the evil spell of the Snow Queen. On her journey she has to contend with the Summer garden witch, the robbers in the wood, and the Snow Queen herself. Only Gerda, helped by birds and animals, has the power to overcome them all.

results.title: The Snow is black = La Neige est noire
results.brief_description: Boy scouts go to the Alps to learn how to ski and to build their confidence. They are taught the techniques of skiing and the idea of group cooperation and friendship. In French with no subtitles.

results.title: The Snapping turtle
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description: Shows the life cycle of a typical reptile, the snapping turtle - its birth, its growth, and its struggle for existence and survival. Natural photography reveals its activities, its encounters with other animal life, how it gets its food and lays its eggs, how its young hatch and develop, and how it hibernates.

results.title: The Snapper
results.creator_credit: Stephen Frears, Lynda Myles and BBC Film Unit
results.brief_description: The Curley’s are a working class Dublin family headed by Dessie, (Colm Meaney), an affable plasterer with a taste for the drink, and Kay, (Ruth McCabe), who keeps their six children in line. This topsy-turvy household falls into a tailspin when 20 year-old Sharon, (Tina Kellegher) announces that she is pregnant. Tensions mount when it becomes obvious that she has no intention of revealing the child’s paternity. As the time approaches for the little “snapper’ to be born, Dessie is becoming a New Age Man while Sharon learns to turn life’s little “accidents’ into big achievements. This is a delightful Irish comedy, well handled by director Frears and with quality performances by Meany and Kellegher.
